climbs.name: The Great Arete
climbs.fa: Todd Swain, Mike Cody (both solo) summer 1980

content.description: On the left (east) wall of the railroad cut is a prominent arête. While short, it's a great little route.
content.location: This route climbs the prominent arête that is about midway through the cut on the left side as you are walking down the railroad tracks.

content.description:
On the downhill and road (E) side of the railroad cut is a 40 or 50 foot high cliff. Climb the right center of this cliff past a flake and a   small birch sapling on the route.  

  It’s likely that other routes could be/have been done here.
content.location: On the downhill and road (east) side of the railroad cut is a 40 or 50 foot high cliff.

content.description: A 200-foot traverse of the left (east) wall of the railroad cut, crossing The Great Arête.
content.location: This route traverses the length of the left (east) wall of the railroad cut.

content.description:
This is the railroad cut through the top of Crawford Notch. There are many boulder problems and several climbs here. 

  [ NOTE: The RR through the notch is active again with a tourist train in summer through "leaf peeping" season. Folk should only climb here during the part of the year when the tracks are not active - late fall through late spring, and even then should be aware they are technically trespassing. (per sign on the tracks) RHall NH Admin.]
